q: said: "I love The Hoff." The first of the judges to arrive was motormouth comic Michael McIntyre , 34, who knew exactly what he was after from the Scottish acts. He said: We've had Subo then we had Janey Cutler. "This year I'm looking for an even older woman. "They are getting older and older. "I'm hoping for a 98-year-old woman to just turn up and blow the roof off the Armadillo. Michael McIntyre and The Hoff took over judges' duties from Piers Morgan and Simon Cowell , who will return for the live TV shows. Also gee-ing up the crowd were pint-sized Geordie presenters Ant and Dec.

Sunday, Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell ( R-Ky.) told host David Letterman Gregory that he did not "have much to add" to what Hillary Clinton had said on how the administration was handling the uprising. I don't have any criticism of Barack Obama or Secretary Hillary Clinton at this point, Mitch McConnell added after he was pressed by Gregory. for an executive who is transitioning out of the CEO role-- and may even be unusual for sitting CEOs, said David Wise, senior principal at consulting firm Hay Group. But given Eric Schmidt 's success, the board clearly wants to retain his guidance for the next four years. "It's a signal to shareholders that he'll continue to steer the boat," Wise added. doctor resigns THE British prime minister's director of communications Andy Coulson has resigned amid accusations that he was aware of phone hacking by his journalists while working as editor of the "News of the World" newspaper. I can today confirm that I've resigned as Downing Street director of communications, Andy Coulson said in a statement. "Unfortunately, continued coverage of events connected to my old job at the "News of the World" has made it difficult for me to give the 110 per cent

The key challenge will be to come up with devices of a quality level and hip factor that helps position Windows Phone as an attractive alternative to iPhone or Android.

unrevealed facts about the six years during which he ran the President Bush - particularly since nearly two-thirds of the book deal with that relatively brief period in the author's life. But, as Donald Rumsfeld writes, he's never much of a handwringer, I don't spend a lot of time in recriminations, looking back or second-guessing decisions made in real time with imperfect information by myself or others. As seems typical of so much here, that's partially true; the author has no taste for self-criticism or second-guessing himself. Masterful bureaucratic survivor that he was until he ran out of room to maneuver
